“You can rip the baby out of the womb of the mother,” Trump blasted. “The government has no business with the decisions that a mother makes,” was Clinton’s reminder that there is nothing freedom-loving about overturning Roe vs Wade.

For the first time, it was the madness of Trump’s ideas rather than his erratic manner that took centre stage during this debate.

For some Republicans, the moments of relative calm, the brief nostalgia of familiar policy proposals, will come as a relief – perhaps just enough to stop his poll numbers plummeting further. For what looks like a growing majority of Americans who have already decided he is too ill-tempered and under-qualified to be president, the reminder that even his policies feel like a bad trip will not have made this a pleasant illusion.

Last week I had a package delivered to my desk containing a lightbulb suggesting I may prefer to have sex with it on because it is dimmer than the average bulb.

It was not a piece of fanmail, but a PR push that began with “research” about how many women felt self conscious about their body during sex.

“We hope this helps you start seeing yourself in a new light – to love how you look and love how you feel,” it said.

Related: Why is women’s body image anxiety at such devastating levels?

The product it was promoting? Weight loss. Specifically, Weight Watchers.

First the weight loss industry came for our enjoyment of the beach intoning “bikini body” from the last day of winter onwards, and now they are coming for the bedroom.

I was inclined to tweet a photo and forget about it. But a week later I am still getting furious responses from women, a visceral reaction which shows this is still something women want to talk about ... despite it being something they are sick of talking about.

This wasn’t just one of the numerous petty insults we are used to every day but something that was thought out for months, strategised, okayed by multiple people.

What is there to be said about weight loss campaigns that hasn’t already been said? Reams have already been written. We know insecurities are exploited for financial gain.

We know there is a relentless and unrealistic pressure put on women to look a certain way from when they were girls.

We know that more often than not, the product being sold just doesn’t work. Women either do not lose weight, or a much smaller number lose the weight and then discover all of their problems are not solved by being thin.

And yet, it is 2016 and I am still receiving a lightbulb in the mail suggesting I might prefer to have sex with the lights off for fear that my partner might, shockingly, see my body.

It’s almost embarrassing to have to write such an obvious point – overweight people enjoy sex, it is not just the domain of the thin. But this campaign isn’t just saying overweight people may not be inclined to show their bodies, it’s also saying any woman could, and perhaps should, be self-conscious taking her clothes off.

No matter your size you are susceptible to this campaign, whether you think you should lose 10kg, 30kg, or 2.5kg there is something in here for everyone. It’s not just about being overweight, it’s about every woman who has ever wished something about their body was different. Which is pretty much all women.

It’s so boring.

This is the thin edge of the Donald Trump wedge, the insidious everyday misogynistic messaging we are telegraphed about how we should look, how it matters. It is the other end of the sexism spectrum to Trump who trumpets it, says bluntly: “She is a fat piglet.”

If there is any silver lining, it is that more and more women are not putting up with this any more. Trump is actually losing votes over his comments and treatment of women. Weight Watchers was forced to respond to the backlash – it hasn’t pulled the campaign but Weight Watchers’ senior marketing manager, Rebecca Melville, conceded it could cause offence.

Related: Fat-shaming is as disgusting as any other prejudice

“We launched in stages and that has fuelled the conversation without context,” she told Mumbrella.

What context do we need? We already know the context: the company commissions the research that says we have a problem with our bodies during sex and, surprise, that company has the product to solve our problem.

It feels like we are stuck in this infinite loop, doomed to keep trying to tell the world our bodies are fine, we are fine.

We are tired. Tired of the commentary on how desirable we are, tired of being warned about summer bodies, tired of being told hair removal and makeup is a statement no matter what our decision on it. We’re tired of all that because there are so many more interesting things we could be talking and thinking about. We have better things to do.

Michael Caiafa was quite literally born into Melbourne’s historic Queen Victoria market.

His mother worked at the family’s gourmet bread and pastry store in the precinct known as “deli hall” right until the moment she went into labour with Caiafa 34 years ago.

“Sadly, mum passed 21 years ago but her legacy lives on, and maybe that’s why I’m still here and maybe that’s why I’m so passionate about it,” he says as his sister serves a customer a seeded loaf.

Related: Almost half of Melbourne’s morning peak trains were overcrowded last year

“Mum started working here when she was 13, and it has been in the family for about 55 years.”

However Caiafa has been lured out from behind the counter of M&G Caiafa, known by regulars as “the corner bread shop”, to enter the world of local politics. It is this market, which spreads over two city blocks and sells everything from cheap souvenirs to fresh produce and truffle-infused cheeses, that has driven him to run on the Melbourne city council ballot as the lead candidate for domestic violence campaigner and independent, Phil Cleary.

They are staunchly opposed to the council’s $250m redevelopment plan for the market, which has heritage listing.

The push for the comprehensive redevelopment, the most expensive and extensive in the market’s history, has become a pet project for the Liberal lord mayor, Robert Doyle. If elected on Saturday he will become the first Melbourne lord mayor to serve three consecutive terms. But if he loses, his council-approved plan for the 140-year-old market, a hodgepodge of art deco detailing and old-world charm, may be the reason why.

What he’s proposing will change the fabric of it

Phil Cleary

In newspaper editorials and on social media, celebrities through to humble traders like Caiafa have weighed in on the plan, which will see trestle tables replaced with fixed trading stalls in open sheds, the carpark abolished and moved underground, and increases in community space.

It may seem like the investment should be welcomed given the roofing is in desperate need of waterproofing, the toilets are dank, and water and electricity access to outdoor fruit and vegetable vendors is almost non-existent. But Cleary and Caiafa feel the redevelopment goes too far.

“Robert Doyle’s plan is promising to sanitise the market and turn it into a food hall-slash-supermarket, and what he’s proposing will change the fabric of it,” Cleary says.

“He’s sending everything underground, the forklifts, the traders, the refrigeration. It’s the antithesis of what the market ought to be. It’s a disgraceful plan that has become symbolic of so many of inner-Melbourne’s problems.”

Cleary believes those problems include high-rise development favoured over preserving open space and community, and increasing overcrowding and congestion. The market’s sprawling mix of traders makes it a place people wander through and take their time, talking to traders who have been there, in some cases, for three generations.

A 40-year resident of Melbourne, actor Sigrid Thornton, is a regular shopper at the market. She says there are enough “sanitised and curated” markets around Melbourne and fears the redevelopment will see the Queen Vic’s character destroyed.

I don’t want the market to be curated, and made into a David Jones food hall

Sigrid Thornton

“I like the fact that it’s a slightly haphazard place, that it’s not especially well planned, and yet it works,” she tells Guardian Australia.

“I like the forklifts and the the bustle. Hiding the working mechanisms of the market underground seems to me a variety of desecration. I don’t want the market to be curated and made into a David Jones food hall. As much as I enjoy David Jones food hall, we have one of those already.”

Like several of the traders spoken to by Guardian Australia, Thornton feels that if the council had properly invested in the market over the past decade, such a drastic redevelopment would not be required now.

“It seems to be a classic move, running something down so you can announce that something exciting and new is being planned, and the tone becomes one of being a rescuer,” she says.

But Doyle rejects claims that the market has been historically neglected, saying the council invested roughly $5m per year in the site. He insists he was not caught off-guard by the protests to his plan or the fight he now has to convince traders and the general public that the overhaul will reap rewards.

“You can go back to the 1950s and you’ll find the councillor who was chair of the marketing committee at the time saying that it was ridiculous the market did not have childcare facilities, or cold and running water,” he says. “Those issues haven’t been addressed to this day, because every time the traders have arced up.”

There comes a point where giving it another coat of paint just doesn’t cut it

Robert Doyle

Doyle says while some traders were resistant, others had told him unless the council made a significant investment, the market may not still be there in 20 years time.

“I’m convinced of the business case we’ve made to the state government for this project,” he says.

“There comes a point where giving it another coat of paint just doesn’t cut it. We’re doing this for the traders, we know visitation will grow by 70% and retail spending will triple within 10 years of us doing this. Independent reports have verified the cost benefits of this.”

He admits briefly that consultation with stallholders about the plans could have been better. A key issue traders have is with the council’s behind-closed-doors negotiations with developers to build an underground car park and childcare centre on the neighbouring council-owned Munro site, and there is anger that traders don’t know where their stalls will be located once their leases, guaranteed until 2022, expire.

But Doyle says it’s unrealistic to expect a plan for where stalls will be located beyond 2022.

“However there is no secret plan to tip people out of the market then,” he says. “I think there is some mischief going on in some of the concerns being raised, given there will be more open space and more people attracted to the market. “

The market, which trades on Tuesdays and Thursday-Sunday, was only being used 40% of the time, Doyle adds.

The council has already experimented with holding night markets on Wednesday nights throughout summer, in which artisan food trucks and live performers fill the asphalt, which usually lies abandoned and dark once the stallholders shut shop for the day.

However the president of the Queen Victoria Market Traders Incorporated and owner of the big Vic Deli, Kon Kardaras, says many traders are opposed to increased pressure for extended trading.

“Our primary concern is that it will shift the focus away from it being a trading place as a market to a civic centre, but the reality is that this is a precinct of family-operated businesses that cannot operate seven days a week,” he says.

“If we go to seven days and later nights we will need to put on more staff, and instead of customers being served by the owner operators they will be served by university students, who will be needed to take on the extra shifts.

“It removes the ownership, knowledge and personality people come to the market for. I have travelled the world making cheeses and salamis and that’s what people come to me for.”

Kardaras favours a more modest redevelopment. He doesn’t want to see trestle tables replaced with individual lock-up spaces sporting drawer-shutters, or casual eateries replaced with fine dining.

“You’re torn between the concept of what is 21st century, and what is attractive,” he says. “Twenty-first century Melbourne is cubicles but is it charming and appealing?”

It’s the charm that attracted Kay Gibson, 68, and her partner Allan Searles, 65, all the way from Brisbane. They made a stop at the market on Tuesday before attending a rock concert in the evening.

“I used to live in Melbourne, and I think [the market] is wonderful,” Gibson says. “I used to come once a fortnight, it’s great to come and buy all your fruits and I love the deli part. I hope whatever they do with it, they remember it’s all about the culture, how you come, walk through and see different foods from all over the place.”

Doyle dismisses concerns the character of the market will be lost.

Part of the reason for the Unesco world heritage listing application was to protect that, he says. He believes what patrons will see at ground level post-development won’t be much different to the look of the market now.

“I don’t think there should be any fear about the feel of the market being lost, there’s no intention to spit-polish it,” he says.

Doyle met with senior representatives from the CFMEU, the Electrical Trades Union Victoria and the Plumbers Union this week to reassure them about the future of the site and that the heritage would be preserved. There has been talk from the unions of implementing a “green ban” on the development works, a form of industrial action to protect culturally and architecturally significant heritage buildings.

“What they wanted was accurate information,” Doyle says. “I believe I managed to reassure them.”

Despite his confidence in the redevelopment plan, Doyle admits to feeling nervous about election day on Saturday.

“No election is ever in the bag and it’s even worse when you’re the purported frontrunner and favourite,” he says.

“The difficulty for me is that with all the preferencing against me although I may win on primaries, bit by bit someone else might leapfrog ahead of me.”

Hillary Clinton condemned Donald Trump’s “scare rhetoric” on abortion after he repeatedly claimed her position meant doctors would be able to “rip the baby out of the womb of the mother” on the day prior to its birth.

The Republican nominee used the graphic language as the pair clashed over the future of the US supreme court and whether he supported overturning Roe v Wade, the landmark 1973 decision that legalized abortion in the United States.

Related: Presidential debate fact-check: Clinton and Trump's claims reviewed

Trump, who has vowed to nominate pro-life justices to the court as president, said the ruling would “automatically” be overturned if he was elected.

During their final encounter on the presidential debate stage, Trump sought to paint a grotesque picture of Clinton’s support for access to abortion.

He said of the Democratic nominee: “If you go with what Hillary is saying, you can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb of the mother just prior to the birth of the baby.”

“You can say that that is OK and Hillary can say that that is OK, but it’s not OK with me.

“Based on what she is saying and based on where she’s going and where she’s been,” he added, “you can take baby and rip the baby out of the womb in the ninth month, on the final day. That’s not acceptable.”

Clinton countered that her stance on the issue was about protecting a woman’s right to choose, while pointing out that late-term abortions were rare.

“Using that kind of scare rhetoric is just terribly unfortunate,” Clinton said of her opponent.

“This is one of the worst possible choices that any woman and her family has to make, and I do not believe the government should be making it.”

Drawing from her record as former secretary of state, Clinton noted she had traveled to countries where governments either forced women to undergo abortions or in other cases to bear children.

“I can tell you the government has no business in the decisions that women make with their families in accordance with their rights,” Clinton said. “And I will stand up for that right.”

While Americans are broadly split on the topic of abortion, a majority of the public supports upholding Roe v Wade.

Republicans have repeatedly campaigned on tearing down the supreme court’s decision. Trump has floated doing as much on the campaign trail and chose as his running mate Mike Pence, who as the governor of Indiana enacted some of the strictest abortion laws in the country. He has also pledged to defund the women’s health organization Planned Parenthood and earlier this year said women should be “punished” for having abortions – a statement he walked back but that Clinton raised at the debate.

Trump’s record on abortion is itself mixed, as he once described himself as “very pro-choice”.
